awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Support for the International Conference on Computational Photography (ICCP) 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of students of all levels (undergraduate, Master’s, doctoral) from US-based institutions in the IEEE International Conference on Computational Photography (ICCP) 2022, to be held as an in-person event between August 1-3, 2022 at the California Institute of Technology, in Pasadena, California. Currently in its fourteenth iteration, ICCP is the premier annual conference dedicated to computational photography, and is organized with the vision of fostering a community of researchers that all converge to this field from traditionally distinct disciplines, including: imaging and optics, imaging and signal processing, vision and graphics, sensors and electronics. The ICCP 2022 program includes keynote and invited talks from the above-mentioned and other communities, paper presentations, poster and demo sessions, and networking events. This program creates rich opportunities for cross-pollination of ideas across research and application areas, and provides both junior and senior researchers with an environment where they can engage in brainstorming and mentoring discourse.

This award facilitates the participation in ICCP 2022 of a diverse group of students, including: students from underrepresented groups; students from research labs that traditionally do not attend ICCP but work on closely-related problems; and students that would not otherwise have the resources to attend. The award provides travel grants for 10 selected US-based students. Applications are solicited broadly from across the US, and recipients of travel grants are selected by the ICCP 2022 program chairs. Each travel grant partially covers travel and lodging costs up to $1000, and includes a conference registration waiver. Recipient students are invited to: attend all aspects all elements of the ICCP 2022 program (paper presentations, keynote talks, invited talks, poster and demo sessions, reception, breaks and networking events); present their research work as a poster at the ICCP 2022 poster sessions; and participate in a mentoring session featuring a panel of junior and senior faculty providing research and career development advice. Overall, the project will support the career development of some of the brightest junior researchers in computational photography, and will increase diversity and student participation in ICCP 2022, and the broader computational photography community. In turn, this will help increase the number of active researchers and educators in STEM, advance the computational photography field, and accelerate the research and development of technologies with broad beneficial societal impacts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award helped create a student travel grant program that supported undergraduate and graduate students from US-based universities to attend the IEEE International Conference on Computational Photography (ICCP) 2022, in Pasadena, CA.

ICCP is organized with the vision of fostering a community of researchers that all converge to computational photography, despite coming from traditionally distinct disciplines, including: imaging and optics, image and signal processing, vision and graphics, sensors and electronics. Topics typically featured in the conference include computational cameras, computational displays, computational illumination and optics, novel and advanced sensor design, high-performance and scientific imaging, advanced signal processing methods, augmented and virtual reality, optical computing, and microscopy. In 2022, ICCP was in its fourteenth year. In the previous decade, it had built a dedicated community of around 300 regular participants from across the areas of computer vision, computer graphics, signal processing, imaging and optics, and sensors and electronics.

Intellectual merit. The funds provided by this award fully covered attendance costs (registration, travel, accommodation, food) for 12 students (approximately 10% of the total student attendees), among whom 50% undergraduate, 50% women, and 20% other under-represented minorities (Black, LGBTQ+).

Students had the opportunity to participate in all conference activities, including: talks from the paper program, keynote talks, invited talks, poster session, demo session, award session, and social events (banquet, photography competition).

Students additionally participated in student-centric activities, including: invited poster presentations, and mentoring sessions between students and faculty.

Lastly, PI Gkioulekas has worked with conference organizers to ensure that the student travel grant program continues in subsequent ICCP iterations, including through NSF support.

Broader impacts. The student travel grant program created through this award helped increase the diversity of research communities represented at ICCP, by supporting students from research groups and research areas that do not traditionally participate at the conference. Thus, the award facilitated cross-pollination of ideas across research communities, and helped advanced science.

Additionally, the student travel grant program created through this award helped increase ICCP participation from women students and students from under-represented ethnic and racial minorities. Increasing representation from these groups in this research area is critical, as their unique backgrounds and experiences helps advance computational photography, and computing research in general, in beneficial ways distinct from those contributed by majority groups.

Lastly, the student travel grant program created through this award helped increase engagement and participation in STEM, by supporting undergraduate students to participate in ICCP 2022. Participation in ICCP 2022 provided undergraduate students with exposure to a truly interdisciplinary research area, a high-profile venue to present their research, and opportunities to form connections with mentors and peers across academia and industry. 


Last Modified: 01/13/2024
Modified by: Ioannis Gkioulekas
